preface.title: Preface
preface.para: This is much of my life's work regarding regarding the non-Jew in Torah from my own personal study. I'm not a Rabbi. I'm a non-Jew who studies Torah and listens to Rabbis. I would like to share with everyone what I've found. These answers were received from my questioning Torah. I think many of us ask that question yet many of us get bogged down and never find definative answers, which demoralize many of us to the point of giving up or disbelief. I like to think this book will convey the things I found that I believe are incumbant on every human-being to know and it would be a personal tragedy if I did not convey it for posterity.

I will use Hebrew words and phrases to help convey the original wisdom in context. Any translations into English are my own. Transliterated words will be italicised. I try to use only Torah sources, but when I deviate, it will most likely be due to problems in English words and their understanding that I need to rectify. Translated words from their original Hebrew often come out as vulgar. I do my best to not be common in my language. There is a balance that must be met between stooping language down for the simple man to understand and between giving the unadulterated wisdom. I think that balance is to use transliterated Hebrew nouns at the very least. If you're reading this book, then that means you must have the aptitude to learn new ideas and new words. We might as well learn the actual Hebrew word in context, rather than a translation that usually bastardizes the original meaning and wisdom of the word.

For most of the book, I'll be using the term bnei Yisrael which is the Hebrew translation for children of Israel. It's common today to refer to bnei Yisrael as "Jews" or the Jewish People, but for the sake of clarity, I'll be using bnei Yisrael instead, which is usually the phrase used in Torah.

If I give my opinion about a matter, I usually preface the statement with "It appears to me" or "In my opinion". I also ask questions that I would like to know answers to. Please contact me by posting your succinct input in our Google Group "Bnei Noach".

This book is organic and living. Instead of having a number of editions, I will be using a version number, similar to that of computer software and only use numbered editions when printing. The source files for the book are housed in a version controlled repository that is constantly being added to, updated, fixed and processed into multiple media formats.

partintro.para: Umot haOlam is translated as "People of the World" and it has a specific definition in CHABAD Chassidut. Within the set of Umot haOlam are specific subsets. Depending on what the set is referring to, these subsets are either subsets entirely, or have some mutual exclusivity, in respect to properties. For instance, all humans have chromosomes, but not all humans keep kosher; it's in respect to the properties talk about.
Every human being takes an oath in utero to be righteous(Niddah 30b, Iyov).
Every human being has 613 bones that desire to do mitzvot.

Every human being who's spirit moves them, can obtain understanding and with his knowledge set himself different and stand before haShem, to serve and minister to Him and to know haShem, walking straight as Elokim made him, and and can remove the yoke of the thoughts of bnei Adam. This human being is sanctified like the Kadosh Kadoshim. haShem is his portion and heritage forever and will provide what is sufficient for him in this world like He provides for priests and Levites. Thus David, peace be upon him, said
Tehillim 16:5 "haShem is my lot and my portion; You are my cup; you support my lot."
Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchot Shemita v'Yovel 13:13
